questions.text: Mallory bodies contain-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cytokeratin. Mallory bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions found in hepatocytes, most commonly in conditions such as alcoholic liver disease, cirrhosis, and non-alcoholic steatohepatitis. These bodies are composed of abnormal intermediate filaments, primarily cytokeratin proteins. The accumulation of misfolded or aggregated cytokeratin filaments leads to the formation of these characteristic inclusion bodies. Cytokeratin is a type of protein found in the cytoskeleton of epithelial cells, and in the case of Mallory bodies, its abnormal aggregation contributes to the pathological features of liver damage. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: A. Vimentin: Vimentin is an intermediate filament protein commonly found in mesenchymal cells, such as fibroblasts, endothelial cells, and smooth muscle cells. While it is an important cytoskeletal protein, Mallory bodies do not primarily contain vimentin. Vimentin is more associated with other types of cellular inclusions or abnormalities, but not specifically Mallory bodies in hepatocytes. C. Desmin: Desmin is an intermediate filament protein primarily found in muscle cells (smooth and skeletal muscle). It plays a key role in maintaining the structure and function of muscle tissue. Desmin is not typically associated with Mallory bodies in the liver, as these inclusions are formed from cytokeratin aggregates, not desmin. D. Collagen: Collagen is a fibrous protein that forms the extracellular matrix and provides structural support to tissues. It is not a component of Mallory bodies. While collagen is important in liver fibrosis, its presence is not a characteristic feature of Mallory bodies, which are composed of cytokeratin, not collagen.

questions.text: All of the following drug induced liver injuries are correctly matched with their causative agents except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Amiodarone: Vascular lesions. Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication known to cause drug-induced liver injury, but its primary liver-related side effects are hepatocellular toxicity and fibrosis, rather than vascular lesions. Amiodarone can cause a spectrum of liver injuries, including fatty liver, hepatitis, and even cirrhosis. The association between amiodarone and vascular lesions is not a characteristic feature. The more common hepatic injury seen with amiodarone is due to its accumulation in the liver, leading to damage and fibrosis, not vascular changes. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: A. Valproate: Fatty liver disease: Valproate, an anticonvulsant and mood-stabilizing drug, is correctly associated with fatty liver disease. Valproate is known to cause a variety of liver-related issues, including hepatocellular damage and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Chronic use of valproate can lead to liver enlargement and fat accumulation in hepatocytes. C. Allopurinol: Fibrin ring granuloma: Allopurinol, a drug used to treat gout, is correctly associated with the formation of fibrin ring granulomas, which are a characteristic finding in allopurinol-induced drug reactions. These granulomas can develop in response to allopurinol, particularly in the context of a hypersensitivity reaction leading to the development of drug-induced hepatitis. D. Angiosarcoma: Vinyl chloride: Vinyl chloride is correctly associated with the development of angiosarcoma, a rare malignant tumor of the blood vessels. Chronic exposure to vinyl chloride, a chemical used in the production of plastics, is a well-established risk factor for the development of hepatic angiosarcoma, a type of liver cancer. This is a well-documented occupational health hazard.

questions.text: The pathway activated in inflammatory type of hepatocellular adenoma is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hepatocellular adenomas: These benign tumors can be further subclassified according to the genetic mutations they harbor, which influence their clinical behavior and risk of malignant transformation. The three main types of HCAs are: HNF1-α inactivated adenomas: These are typically benign and associated with oral contraceptive (OC) use or individuals with Maturity Onset Diabetes of the Young (MODY-3). There is virtually no risk of malignant transformation in this group. β-Catenin-activated adenomas: These tumors are associated with mutations in the β-catenin gene, which leads to marked atypia. They are known to have a very high risk for malignant transformation into hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Inflammatory adenomas: These adenomas are characterized by upregulation of acute-phase reactants such as C-reactive protein and serum amyloid A, often due to mutations in the gp130 gene. Inflammatory adenomas are at intermediate risk for malignant transformation, and some may also harbor β-catenin activating mutations, which further increase their risk of malignancy. Incorrect options: A. Hepatocellular carcinoma: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a primary liver malignancy and differs from hepatocellular adenomas, as it is a malignant tumor rather than a benign one. HCC is often associated with chronic liver diseases such as cirrhosis or viral hepatitis, not the molecular changes typical of HCAs. C. Cholangiocarcinoma: Cholangiocarcinoma is a malignancy of the bile ducts and is a distinct entity from hepatocellular adenomas. It arises from the epithelial cells of the biliary tract and is associated with conditions like primary sclerosing cholangitis or chronic inflammation of the bile ducts. D. Hemangioma: Hemangiomas are benign vascular lesions and are different from hepatocellular adenomas. They are the most common benign liver lesions but do not involve hepatocytes, and they lack the molecular subtypes seen in hepatocellular adenomas.

questions.text: Perivenular fibrosis is caused by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Alcohol The correct answer is B. Alcohol. Alcohol-induced liver injury is a well-known cause of perivenular fibrosis. Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to a variety of liver pathologies, including fatty liver, alcoholic hepatitis, and ultimately cirrhosis. In alcoholic liver disease, perivenular fibrosis typically occurs around the central veins (venules) in the liver. This fibrosis is part of the overall hepatic damage caused by alcohol, where there is an increase in collagen deposition in the perivenular region due to inflammation and cellular injury. This fibrosis can progress to cirrhosis if alcohol consumption is continued over time. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is an immunosuppressive drug commonly used to treat diseases like rheumatoid arthritis and certain cancers. While it can cause liver toxicity, it typically leads to macrovesicular steatosis (fatty liver), fibrosis, and cirrhosis, but perivenular fibrosis is not its hallmark. Methotrexate-induced liver injury often manifests as hepatocellular damage and can lead to fibrosis but not specifically in the perivenular area. C. OCPs (Oral Contraceptive Pills): Oral contraceptive pills are known to cause a range of liver issues, including hepatic adenomas, cholestasis, and peliosis hepatis. However, perivenular fibrosis is not a typical feature of OCP-related liver damage. The liver damage from OCPs is often linked to hormonal effects, leading to conditions like hepatic tumors or benign lesions, not primarily to fibrosis around the central veins. D. Amiodarone: Amiodarone, an antiarrhythmic medication, can cause liver toxicity, which may lead to hepatocellular injury, hepatomegaly, or cirrhosis. However, perivenular fibrosis is not the most typical pattern of fibrosis associated with amiodarone-induced liver injury. The liver changes due to amiodarone often include hepatocellular ballooning and lipid accumulation in the cytoplasm, leading to a more diffuse fibrosis pattern rather than a specific perivenular fibrosis.

questions.text: Hallmark of chronic hepatitis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Periportal fibrosis and bridging fibrosis The hallmark of chronic hepatitis is periportal fibrosis and bridging fibrosis. Chronic hepatitis is characterized by long-standing liver inflammation, which leads to the development of fibrosis over time. In the initial stages, fibrosis may be limited to the periportal areas, which is the region around the portal tracts. As the disease progresses, fibrosis can extend, creating bridges between portal tracts and central veins. This process of fibrosis can eventually lead to cirrhosis if the underlying cause is not controlled. Therefore, periportal fibrosis and bridging fibrosis are key features in the pathophysiology of chronic hepatitis. Explanation for Incorrect Answers: A. Steatosis: While steatosis (fatty liver) is commonly seen in a variety of liver diseases, including chronic hepatitis, it is not the hallmark of chronic hepatitis. Steatosis often occurs due to factors like alcohol consumption, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), or drug-induced liver injury. However, the characteristic feature of chronic hepatitis is fibrosis, particularly periportal and bridging fibrosis, rather than steatosis alone. B. Ballooning degeneration of hepatocytes: Ballooning degeneration is a form of hepatocyte injury that can be seen in acute hepatitis and in the early stages of chronic hepatitis. It occurs when hepatocytes swell due to damage from inflammatory mediators. While ballooning degeneration can be observed in chronic hepatitis, it is not the hallmark of chronic hepatitis. Ballooning degeneration is more indicative of acute hepatocellular injury or more advanced stages of liver injury rather than the characteristic fibrosis seen in chronic hepatitis. C. Cholestasis: Cholestasis, the reduction or stoppage of bile flow, can be seen in some chronic liver diseases, including chronic hepatitis, but it is not the hallmark feature. Cholestasis might be more commonly associated with cholestatic liver diseases such as primary biliary cirrhosis or primary sclerosing cholangitis, rather than chronic hepatitis. In chronic hepatitis, the primary feature is inflammation and fibrosis, particularly periportal fibrosis.

questions.text: A 1 month old child with conjugated billirubinemia and intrahepatic cholestasis. On Liver biopsy and staining with PAS red coloured granules were seen inside the hepatocytes. Probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • PAS-positive, diastase-resistant red granules in hepatocytes ? this is characteristic of A1AT deficiency. • These granules represent accumulated misfolded A1AT protein. Why not the others? B. Congenital hepatic fibrosis • Usually presents later in childhood, not at 1 month. • Not associated with PAS-positive granules. • Biopsy shows fibrosis and bile duct proliferation, not A1AT globules. C. Wilson disease • Presents later (typically after age 5), with neuropsychiatric and hepatic symptoms. • Diagnosis involves low ceruloplasmin, Kayser–Fleischer rings, and copper accumulation, not PAS-positive granules. D. Hereditary hemochromatosis • Adult-onset, very rare in infancy. • Iron deposits stain with Prussian blue, not PAS. • Affects liver, pancreas, heart, but not in a 1-month-old.

questions.text: Most common gene responsible for hereditary hemochromatosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) HFE gene: Hereditary hemochromatosis is most commonly caused by mutations in the HFE gene, which is located on chromosome 6. The most common mutation is the C282Y mutation in the HFE gene, leading to impaired regulation of iron absorption in the small intestine. This results in excessive iron accumulation in various organs, such as the liver, heart, and pancreas. The condition is typically autosomal recessive, meaning both copies of the gene must have mutations for the disease to manifest. The HFE gene is responsible for controlling the body's iron homeostasis, and mutations lead to abnormal iron metabolism and the clinical features of hemochromatosis. Incorrect options: A. HIV gene: The HIV gene refers to the genetic material of the human immunodeficiency virus. It has no association with hereditary hemochromatosis. HIV infection can cause various symptoms, including immunosuppression, but it is unrelated to iron metabolism disorders such as hemochromatosis. B. HAMP gene: The HAMP gene encodes hepcidin, a key regulator of iron homeostasis. While mutations in the HAMP gene can contribute to juvenile hemochromatosis (a rarer, early-onset form of hemochromatosis), it is not the most common cause of hereditary hemochromatosis, which is primarily due to mutations in the HFE gene. C. TfR2 gene: The TfR2 gene encodes the transferrin receptor 2, which is also involved in iron regulation. Mutations in the TfR2 gene can cause a form of hemochromatosis, but this is much less common compared to the HFE gene mutations that account for the majority of hereditary hemochromatosis cases.

questions.text: Most common gene associated with pancreatic cancer:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) KRAS: The KRAS gene is the most commonly mutated gene in pancreatic cancer, with mutations present in approximately 90% of cases. KRAS is a key oncogene that plays a significant role in cell signaling pathways that control cell growth and survival. Mutations in KRAS lead to the constitutive activation of the RAS signaling pathway, promoting uncontrolled cell division, a hallmark of cancer. These mutations are early events in pancreatic cancer development and are found in the majority of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinomas. Incorrect options: B. SMAD: The SMAD gene family is involved in the transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β) signaling pathway, which plays a role in regulating cell growth, differentiation, and apoptosis. While mutations in SMAD genes can contribute to the progression of various cancers, they are not as frequently associated with pancreatic cancer as KRAS mutations. SMAD mutations are more commonly seen in other cancer types, such as colorectal cancer. C. P53: P53 is a tumor suppressor gene that is commonly mutated in a variety of cancers, including pancreatic cancer. P53 mutations are associated with tumor progression and resistance to chemotherapy. However, KRAS mutations occur earlier in the development of pancreatic cancer and are more prevalent. While P53 mutations contribute to the malignant transformation of cells, they are not as common as KRAS mutations in pancreatic cancer. D. Rb: The Rb gene is another tumor suppressor gene, and mutations in Rb can lead to uncontrolled cell cycle progression. However, mutations in Rb are more often associated with cancers such as retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma. In pancreatic cancer, KRAS mutations play a more central role in tumorigenesis, with Rb mutations being less common.

questions.text: Maximum malignant potential is of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Familial adenomatous polyposis Familial adenomatous polyposis is an inherited condition with neoplastic polyps, whereas JPS and PJP are classified under non neoplastic hamartomatous polyps. Ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease comprise the spectrum of inflammatory bowel disease and therefore also carry a risk of colorectal cancer (equal incidence).

questions.text: Lymphoid aggregates in the form of follicles are seen in which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hepatitis C: In Hepatitis C, lymphoid aggregates in the form of follicles are a characteristic histopathological feature. These aggregates consist of clusters of lymphocytes, often with germinal centers, and are typically seen in the portal areas of the liver. This finding reflects the chronic immune response and lymphocytic infiltration that occurs due to the ongoing viral infection. The presence of these follicular aggregates is an important diagnostic feature, especially in chronic Hepatitis C infection, where it indicates the ongoing activation of the immune system. Incorrect options: A. Hepatitis A: Hepatitis A infection generally does not show lymphoid aggregates in the liver. The typical liver histology in Hepatitis A is marked by hepatocellular ballooning, necrosis, and mononuclear cell infiltration in the portal areas. There is no significant formation of lymphoid follicles in this type of viral hepatitis. B. Hepatitis B: While Hepatitis B infection can lead to chronic inflammation, it is not typically associated with the formation of lymphoid aggregates in the liver. Instead, the histopathology of Hepatitis B may show ground-glass hepatocytes, portal inflammation, and in some cases, periportal fibrosis. However, lymphoid follicles are not a characteristic finding in Hepatitis B. D. Hepatitis D: Hepatitis D infection is a co-infection or superinfection that occurs only in individuals who are already infected with Hepatitis B. Like Hepatitis B, Hepatitis D does not typically cause lymphoid aggregates. It is more associated with severe liver injury and may show histopathological features like hepatocyte necrosis and inflammation but not the characteristic lymphoid follicles seen in Hepatitis C.

questions.text: All of the following features can help differentiate Crohn’s disease from Ulcerative colitis except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Crypt Abscess: Crypt abscesses are a feature of Ulcerative Colitis, not Crohn's disease. These abscesses form when neutrophils accumulate in the crypts of the colonic mucosa, leading to abscess formation. This finding is characteristic of Ulcerative Colitis, a condition that primarily affects the mucosal and submucosal layers of the colon and rectum. In contrast, Crohn's disease typically involves the full thickness of the bowel wall (transmural inflammation) and does not commonly present with crypt abscesses. Incorrect options: A. Granuloma formation: Granulomas are a hallmark feature of Crohn's disease and can help differentiate it from Ulcerative Colitis. Granulomas are clusters of macrophages and other immune cells, which are seen in the affected areas of Crohn's disease and reflect the chronic inflammatory process. Granulomas are not typically seen in Ulcerative Colitis, making this an important distinguishing feature. C. Transmural inflammation: Crohn's disease is characterized by transmural inflammation, meaning it affects the entire thickness of the bowel wall, from mucosa to serosa. This feature can lead to complications like strictures, fistulas, and abscesses. Ulcerative Colitis, on the other hand, is limited to the mucosa and submucosa, making transmural inflammation a feature that distinguishes Crohn's disease from Ulcerative Colitis. D. Pseudopolyps: Pseudopolyps are a feature of Ulcerative Colitis, where areas of mucosal healing and regeneration create projections that resemble polyps but are not true neoplastic growths. These pseudopolyps can be seen in both conditions, but they are more commonly associated with the healing phases of Ulcerative Colitis, especially after acute flare-ups. However, the presence of pseudopolyps does not strongly differentiate the two diseases compared to features like granuloma formation or transmural inflammation.

questions.text: Tumor marker(s) associated with both colon cancer and pancreatic cancer is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CEA (Carcinoembryonic Antigen): CEA is a tumor marker that is associated with both colon cancer and pancreatic cancer. It is a glycoprotein that is often elevated in various types of cancers, including colorectal and pancreatic cancers. CEA levels can be monitored in patients with these cancers to assess the response to treatment or detect recurrence. However, CEA is not highly specific, as elevated levels can also be seen in other conditions, such as inflammatory bowel disease, liver disease, and smoking. Incorrect options: B. CA-125: CA-125 is primarily a tumor marker used in the diagnosis and monitoring of ovarian cancer. While it can be elevated in other conditions, including endometriosis, pelvic inflammatory disease, and some benign tumors, it is not associated with colon cancer or pancreatic cancer as strongly as CEA. C. CA 15-3: CA 15-3 is a tumor marker most commonly associated with breast cancer. It is used to monitor the treatment and recurrence of breast cancer, but it is not a significant marker for colon cancer or pancreatic cancer. D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because CA-125 and CA 15-3 are not relevant tumor markers for both colon cancer and pancreatic cancer. The correct answer is CEA, which is the only marker listed that is associated with both of these cancers.

questions.text: Mallory Denk bodies are composed of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cytokeratin 8/18: Mallory-Denk bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies found in hepatocytes and are primarily composed of cytokeratin 8 and cytokeratin 18. These proteins are intermediate filaments that form the structural framework in hepatocytes, and their accumulation within the cell leads to the formation of Mallory-Denk bodies. This finding is commonly seen in liver diseases such as alcoholic liver disease and non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Incorrect options: B. Cytokeratin 5/6: Cytokeratins 5/6 are intermediate filament proteins found in the basal layer of epithelial cells and are commonly used as markers for squamous epithelium or epidermal basal cells. These cytokeratins are not involved in the formation of Mallory-Denk bodies. C. Vimentin: Vimentin is another type of intermediate filament protein, but it is expressed in mesenchymal cells, such as fibroblasts, endothelial cells, and smooth muscle cells, rather than hepatocytes. Vimentin is not a component of Mallory-Denk bodies, which are primarily composed of cytokeratins 8 and 18. D. Cytokeratin 20: Cytokeratin 20 is typically found in gastrointestinal epithelium, particularly in the colon and enterocytes, as well as in certain carcinomas, such as colorectal cancer. It is not involved in the formation of Mallory-Denk bodies in liver cells.

questions.text: The following gross image of liver shows
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Involvement of the liver by metastatic malignancy is far more common than primary hepatic neoplasia. Although the most common primary sources are the colon, breast, lung, and pancreas, any cancer in any site of the body may spread to the liver. Typically, multiple nodular metastases are found that often cause striking hepatomegaly and replace much of the normal liver parenchyma. The liver weight can exceed several kilograms.

questions.text: Councilman bodies are seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Yellow fever cell death resulting in hepatocyte shrinkage, nuclear chromatin condensation (pyknosis), fragmentation (karyorrhexis), and cellular fragmentation into acidophilic apoptotic bodies. Apoptotic hepatocytes were first clearly described in yellow fever by William Thomas Councilman and therefore have often been referred to as Councilman bodies; while apoptosis occurs in many forms of liver disease, by convention this eponym is restricted to that disease. In the more frequent settings in which apoptotic hepatocytes are seen, (e.g., acute and chronic hepatitis), the term acidophil bodies is used, due to their deeply eosinophilic staining characteristics

questions.text: Piecemeal necrosis on liver biopsy is a feature of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Chronic active hepatitis: Piecemeal necrosis refers to the destruction of hepatocytes at the portal tract with a characteristic appearance of lymphocytic infiltration and hepatocyte necrosis that extends into the surrounding liver parenchyma. This feature is pathognomonic for chronic active hepatitis, particularly in conditions like autoimmune hepatitis. The term "piecemeal" describes the way hepatocyte necrosis occurs in a fragmented manner, typically around the portal tracts, which is a hallmark of active inflammation seen in chronic forms of hepatitis. Incorrect options: A. Alcoholic hepatitis: Alcoholic hepatitis is characterized by hepatocellular injury and inflammation primarily in the centrilobular regions of the liver. It often features ballooning degeneration, Mallory bodies, and neutrophilic infiltration, but piecemeal necrosis is not a characteristic feature. Alcoholic hepatitis tends to show a more diffuse pattern of injury without the specific pattern of necrosis seen in chronic active hepatitis. B. Indian childhood cirrhosis: Indian childhood cirrhosis is a rare liver disease in children, primarily affecting the liver with a progressive course leading to cirrhosis. This condition is associated with increased copper deposition and hepatocellular damage but does not typically feature piecemeal necrosis. Histologically, it may show features like bridging fibrosis and macrovesicular steatosis, but not the characteristic "piecemeal" pattern of necrosis. D. Primary alcoholic cirrhosis: Primary alcoholic cirrhosis (or alcoholic cirrhosis) refers to advanced liver damage from chronic alcohol use, which eventually leads to cirrhosis. The histological changes are more consistent with fibrosis, bridging fibrosis, and nodular regeneration rather than piecemeal necrosis. The necrotic patterns seen in alcoholic cirrhosis are usually more diffuse and associated with fibrosis rather than the well-defined, portal-based necrosis of chronic active hepatitis.

questions.text: Chromosome involved in Wilson’s disease
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Chromosome 13 Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder that causes abnormal copper metabolism leading to copper accumulation in various tissues, particularly the liver and brain. The disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which is located on chromosome 13. This gene encodes a copper-transporting ATPase that is essential for the proper incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin and the excretion of excess copper into the bile. Mutations in ATP7B result in copper buildup, causing tissue damage, particularly in the liver (leading to cirrhosis) and the basal ganglia (leading to neurological symptoms). Incorrect options: A. Chromosome 11: Chromosome 11 is not associated with Wilson's disease. However, it is the location of several other important genes related to different diseases, such as the beta-globin gene in sickle cell anemia, but it does not play a role in copper metabolism or Wilson’s disease. B. Chromosome 12: Chromosome 12 is not involved in Wilson's disease. This chromosome contains genes related to other conditions, but it is not the locus of the ATP7B gene, which is specifically responsible for Wilson’s disease. D. Chromosome 14: Chromosome 14 also does not contain the ATP7B gene. While other genetic disorders are linked to chromosome 14, Wilson's disease is not one of them. Therefore, this chromosome is not relevant to the pathogenesis of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: Massive hepatocellular necrosis is seen with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Acetaminophen Acetaminophen, especially in overdose, is known to cause massive hepatocellular necrosis. When taken in excessive amounts, acetaminophen is metabolized by the liver into N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI), a highly toxic metabolite. Under normal conditions, NAPQI is detoxified by glutathione. However, in overdose situations, the glutathione reserves are depleted, allowing NAPQI to bind to hepatocyte proteins, resulting in cell damage and massive liver necrosis. This condition can progress rapidly to acute liver failure if not treated promptly with N-acetylcysteine, which replenishes glutathione. Incorrect responses: A. Tetracycline: Tetracycline can cause liver toxicity, but it is typically associated with a milder form of liver injury, such as cholestatic jaundice or hepatocellular injury. It is not commonly linked to the degree of damage seen with acetaminophen overdose, which can lead to massive hepatocellular necrosis. The hepatotoxicity from tetracycline is usually less severe and generally reversible after discontinuing the drug. B. Macrolides: Macrolides like erythromycin and azithromycin can also cause liver toxicity, but they are more frequently associated with hepatitis or cholestatic jaundice, rather than massive hepatocellular necrosis. While liver damage from macrolides can be significant, it is typically less severe and does not usually result in the extensive necrosis seen with acetaminophen toxicity. C. Methyldopa: Methyldopa, an antihypertensive medication, can cause liver dysfunction and hepatitis in some patients, but it is not typically associated with massive hepatocellular necrosis. The liver injury due to methyldopa is usually milder and more likely to present as hepatitis or cholestasis, which is different from the severe liver necrosis observed with acetaminophen overdose.

questions.text: Fibrin ring granuloma in liver is caused by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Allopurinol Allopurinol, a drug used primarily to treat gout by reducing uric acid levels, is associated with the formation of fibrin ring granulomas in the liver. These granulomas are characterized by a central area of necrosis surrounded by a ring of fibrin, which can be seen in liver biopsies of patients on allopurinol. This reaction is thought to be part of an immune-mediated hypersensitivity response to the drug. Though rare, fibrin ring granulomas are a known histopathological feature associated with allopurinol use. Incorrect responses: A. Sulfonamides: Sulfonamides, while capable of causing drug-induced liver injury (DILI) and hepatitis, are not associated with the formation of fibrin ring granulomas in the liver. Sulfonamides typically cause hypersensitivity reactions, but granulomas are not a characteristic feature of this class of drugs. B. Amiodarone: Amiodarone, used to treat arrhythmias, is known to cause hepatotoxicity, which may manifest as hepatocellular damage or cholestasis. However, amiodarone does not lead to the formation of fibrin ring granulomas. The liver damage from amiodarone is different and does not involve granulomas. C. Isoniazid: Isoniazid, a first-line agent for tuberculosis, is another drug that can cause hepatotoxicity, including hepatitis, but like sulfonamides and amiodarone, fibrin ring granulomas are not associated with isoniazid. Liver damage due to isoniazid typically presents as hepatocellular injury rather than granulomatous reactions.

questions.text: Peliosis hepatis is caused by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anabolic steroids Peliosis hepatis is a rare liver condition characterized by the formation of blood-filled cystic spaces within the liver. Anabolic steroids, which are synthetic derivatives of the male sex hormone testosterone, are strongly associated with this condition. The exact mechanism is not fully understood, but anabolic steroids can lead to vascular changes and hepatocellular damage, contributing to the formation of these blood-filled spaces. Peliosis hepatis is most commonly observed in individuals who have been using anabolic steroids, especially when taken in large doses over extended periods. Incorrect responses: A. Contraceptives: Oral contraceptives have been linked to liver conditions such as hepatic adenomas or cholestasis but are not commonly associated with peliosis hepatis. Although oral contraceptives can cause various types of liver damage, they do not typically lead to the formation of blood-filled cysts in the liver as seen in peliosis hepatis. C. Erythromycin: Erythromycin, a macrolide antibiotic, is not a known cause of peliosis hepatis. While erythromycin can cause hepatotoxicity (e.g., cholestasis or hepatitis), it does not lead to the characteristic cystic vascular changes seen in peliosis hepatis. It primarily affects liver function in other ways, such as causing liver enzyme elevations or cholestasis. D. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe, a medication used to lower cholesterol, has not been implicated in causing peliosis hepatis. Its mechanism of action is to inhibit the absorption of cholesterol in the intestine, and while it may cause some mild liver enzyme elevation in rare cases, it does not lead to the formation of blood-filled cysts in the liver.

questions.text: Macrovesicular fatty change in hepatocytes is seen due to infection with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hepatitis C Macrovesicular fatty change in hepatocytes refers to the accumulation of large fat droplets within the liver cells, often seen in liver diseases. It is commonly associated with Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. The virus causes chronic liver inflammation, leading to the development of steatosis (fatty liver). This type of fatty change can occur even without cirrhosis, and it is a well-known feature of HCV infection, particularly in individuals with chronic infection who may also have alcohol use or metabolic syndrome as contributing factors. Fatty liver is often observed in HCV-related chronic liver disease. Incorrect responses: A. Hepatitis A: Hepatitis A is an acute viral infection caused by the Hepatitis A virus (HAV), which typically does not result in macrovesicular fatty change in hepatocytes. While HAV can cause acute liver inflammation, fatty change is less common in the early stages of infection. The liver damage in Hepatitis A is usually reversible once the virus is cleared, and fatty change is not a hallmark of this infection. B. Hepatitis B: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection may also lead to liver inflammation, but it is not typically associated with macrovesicular fatty change to the same extent as Hepatitis C. While HBV can cause liver damage and, in some cases, lead to steatosis, fatty change is generally less pronounced than in HCV infections. HBV infection often progresses to more significant forms of liver damage, such as cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma, without the prominence of fatty change. D. Hepatitis D: Hepatitis D virus (HDV) infection occurs only in those who are already infected with Hepatitis B (co-infection) and typically results in more severe liver disease, such as cirrhosis. While HDV can cause significant liver damage, including necrosis, fibrosis, and cirrhosis, it is not commonly associated with macrovesicular fatty change. The pathology of Hepatitis D is more related to inflammation and fibrosis rather than the fatty infiltration seen in Hepatitis C.

questions.text: Microvesicular fatty liver is caused by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Valproate Microvesicular fatty liver is characterized by the presence of small fat droplets dispersed throughout the hepatocytes. One of the primary causes of microvesicular fatty liver is the use of the medication Valproate, an anticonvulsant and mood-stabilizing drug. Valproate is known to cause mitochondrial dysfunction, which impairs the liver's ability to metabolize fatty acids, leading to the accumulation of small fat droplets in the liver cells. This condition is considered a drug-induced liver injury and can potentially progress to hepatotoxicity if left unchecked. Incorrect responses: A. DM (Diabetes Mellitus): Diabetes Mellitus (especially Type 2 DM) is commonly associated with macrovesicular fatty liver (steatosis), rather than microvesicular fatty liver. Macrovesicular fatty liver results from an imbalance in lipid metabolism, particularly involving insulin resistance and excess fat accumulation in the liver. While diabetes is a risk factor for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), microvesicular fatty liver is not a typical feature. C. Starvation: Starvation can lead to fatty liver, but typically this results in macrovesicular fatty liver due to the breakdown of fat stores to provide energy. In prolonged starvation or malnutrition, the liver accumulates fat as it tries to compensate for the energy deficit. However, microvesicular fatty liver is not a characteristic of starvation; instead, starvation more commonly causes macrovesicular steatosis due to excess lipid mobilization. D. IBD (Inflammatory Bowel Disease): Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), including conditions like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, is associated with a variety of liver manifestations, such as primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). However, microvesicular fatty liver is not specifically characteristic of IBD. IBD more commonly presents with macrovesicular steatosis or other liver complications, such as cirrhosis and cholestasis, rather than microvesicular fatty liver.

questions.text: Gene of Wilson’s disease is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) ATP7B Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder that leads to copper accumulation in the body, primarily affecting the liver, brain, and corneas. The disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, located on chromosome 13. This gene encodes a copper-transporting ATPase responsible for incorporating copper into ceruloplasmin and for excreting excess copper into bile. A defect in ATP7B results in impaired copper excretion, leading to copper buildup in various tissues, particularly in the liver and brain, which causes damage and dysfunction. Hence, ATP7B is the correct gene associated with Wilson's disease. Incorrect responses: A. ATP7A: ATP7A is a gene associated with another copper metabolism disorder called Menke's disease, which affects copper transport in the body. Unlike Wilson’s disease, where copper accumulates, Menke's disease results in copper deficiency. ATP7A is not the gene involved in Wilson’s disease, making this answer incorrect. C. ADP7A: There is no such gene as ADP7A. This is likely a typographical error or confusion with the ATP7A gene, which is associated with Menke's disease. Therefore, this option is not a valid answer. D. ADP7B: ADP7B is also not a recognized gene in relation to Wilson's disease or any other known genetic disorder. The correct gene for Wilson's disease is ATP7B (not ADP7B). Thus, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Most common benign tumor of liver is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hemangioma The most common benign tumor of the liver is a hemangioma. These are vascular lesions, composed of clusters of blood vessels, and are usually asymptomatic. Hemangiomas are frequently detected incidentally during imaging studies (such as ultrasound or CT scans) performed for other reasons. They are often small and have a characteristic appearance on imaging, making them relatively easy to diagnose. Hemangiomas are generally considered benign and do not usually require treatment unless they cause symptoms, which is rare. Incorrect responses: A. Adenoma: Hepatic adenomas are another type of benign liver tumor but are less common than hemangiomas. These are typically seen in young women, especially those taking oral contraceptives. While they may grow larger and cause symptoms like abdominal pain or discomfort, they have a small risk of malignant transformation. Therefore, although adenomas are benign, they are not the most common type. C. Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH): Focal nodular hyperplasia is another benign liver lesion that is more common than adenomas but less frequent than hemangiomas. FNH is characterized by a central scar and is typically asymptomatic. While it is benign and often requires no treatment, it is not as common as hemangiomas in the liver. D. Hepatoblastoma: Hepatoblastoma is a malignant liver tumor that primarily affects infants and young children. This is not a benign tumor and is significantly less common compared to hemangiomas. Hepatoblastomas are typically associated with poor prognosis if not treated early and are not a benign tumor type

choices.text: Blockage of the common bile duct

questions.text: A 46-years-old woman who is clearly jaundiced is seen in clinic. Laboratory tests reveal conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Urine bilirubin levels are significantly above normal, while urine urobilinogen levels are significantly below normal. Which of the following mechanisms is the most likely cause of her jaundice?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Blockage of the common bile duct Cholestasis due to obstruction of the common bile duct results in an increase in suerm conjugated bilirubin, an increase in urine bilirubin, and a decrease in urine urobilinogen. This form of jaundice is caused by a deficit in bilirubin excretion, since of the process of bilirubin excretion, since the process of bilirubin conjugation is normal. Because the conjugated bilirubin cannot be excreted through the biliary tree, it refluxes back into the serum, resulting in increases serum and urine bilirubin levels. In addition, because very little (if any) of the bilirubin is excreted into the gastrointestinal tract, there is very little urobilinogen produced by the enteric flora, resulting in decreased urobilinogen levels.

questions.text: A 36-years-old alcoholic man is brought to the emergency department because he is jaundiced and exhibits inappropriate somnolence. Past medical history is significant for depression and seizures, both of which are well controlled with medications. Physical exam is significant for citrus, asterixis, and tachypnea. Slit lamp examination revelas greenish-golden crescents on the cornea. AST is 2489 IU/L, ALT is 4873 IU/L, bilirubin is 29 mg/dL, alkal.ine phosphatase is 112 IU/L, hematocrit is 29%, prothrombin time (PT) is 19.1 seconds, and serum ceruloplasmin is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely-diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (E) Wilson disease Acute liver failure (implied by the abnormal liver function tests) in this young patient with depression strongly suggests Wilson disease (WD). In conjunction with a low serum ceruloplasmin level, the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings (greenish-golden crescents on the cornea) on the lamp examination is diagnostic of WD.

questions.text: A 7-years-old boy with chickenpox is given aspirin to reduce his fever. He develops severe vomiting, mental status changes, and seizures, and eventually falls into a coma. Which of the following would you expect to see on a biopsy specimen of his liver?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Fatty change This is a two-step question. First, you need to make a diagnosis. In this case, the combination of viral illness plus aspirin followed by neurologic symptoms should have led you straight to the diagnosis of Reye syndrome. Next, what are the liver changes associated with this condition? The answer is that the liver will characteristically show microvesicular fatty changes. Note that the neurologic symptoms result from encephalopathy and that the brain will develop cerebral edema that may lead to herniation.

questions.text: A 40-years-old woman with polycythemia vera (most common) develops progressive severe ascites and tender hepatomegaly over a period of several months. Liver function tests are near normal. Which of the following tests would be most likely to establish the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hepatic venography The clinical presentation is most consistent with Budd-Chiari syndrome (hepatic vein obstruction), which may occur as a complication of thrombogenic and myeloproliferative disorders including polycythemia vera. The presentation illustrated is the most common; alternative presentations include fulminate liver failure and cases in which intractable abdominal pain is the most prominent initial finding. Hepatic venography is the best technique of those listed to demonstrate the occlusion of the hepatic venous system.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with sickle cell anemia presents with recurrent severe right upper quadrant colicky abdominal pain. At the time of surgery, multiple dark black stones are found within the gallbladder. These stones are composed of which one of the following substances?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bilirubin Gallstones, which affect 10 to 20% of the adult population in developed countries, are divided into two main types: cholesterol stones and bilirubin stones. Cholesterol stones are more common overall, but bilirubin stones are more frequent in individuals with chronic hemolytic disorders, such as sickle cell anemia and thalassemia. These pigment stones are brown or black in color and are composed of bilirubin calcium salts.

questions.text: A patient presents with liver failure and congestive heart failure, and a liver biopsy shows the following changes.What materials abnormal accumulation results in cellular injury and death in this disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Iron The photomicrograph demonstrates abnormal accumulation of iron in the hepatocytes, which stains blue on Prussian blue stain. Patients with hemochromatosis have abnormal iron absorption regulation; systemic increased deposition of iron in otherwise normal tissues results in damage, and cell loss results in liver and heart failure. Abnormal calcium deposition can result in dystrophic and metastatic calcifications. Typically presents as microcalcifications on mammography

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman has a breast biopsy (see Figure 6-10). All of the following statements regarding this lesion are true except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Typically presents as microcalcifications on mammography The photomicrograph demonstrates an example of classical invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast, characterized by discohesive malignant cells infiltrating the stroma in a linear or “Indian-file” arrangement. Classical lobular carcinoma is almost always well differentiated with minimal nuclear atypia, and these tumors are usually estrogen receptor-positive and HER2-negative. The absence of staining for E-cadherin is distinctive, and over half of invasive lobular carcinomas have truncating mutations in the E-cadherin gene. The presence of intracytoplasmic mucin droplets, which are periodic acid Schiff or mucin positive, is also distinctive, although other tumors can show similar changes.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman is diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. She is at the greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Polyarteritis nodosa. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a vasculitis that commonly affects medium-sized arteries and is strongly associated with chronic infections, including hepatitis B. Patients with hepatitis B infection, particularly those who are chronically infected, are at an increased risk of developing PAN due to the formation of immune complexes and subsequent inflammation of blood vessels. PAN in this context is often a consequence of immune complex deposition, which can lead to vascular inflammation and tissue ischemia. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: A. Churg–Strauss disease: Churg–Strauss disease (also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a form of eosinophilic vasculitis that is typically associated with asthma and eosinophilia, rather than infections like hepatitis B. It involves small to medium-sized vessels and is characterized by systemic involvement, particularly in the lungs and skin, but it is not directly linked to hepatitis B infection. B. Hypersensitivity vasculitis: Hypersensitivity vasculitis (or immune complex vasculitis) can be caused by various triggers, including drugs, infections, and autoimmune diseases. While hepatitis B can cause immune complex deposition, hypersensitivity vasculitis is more commonly linked to a broader array of triggers, not specifically to hepatitis B. This makes it less associated with hepatitis B than polyarteritis nodosa. D. Takayasu arteritis: Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis that primarily affects young women, often with a predilection for the aorta and its major branches. It is typically unrelated to infections like hepatitis B. Takayasu arteritis is often associated with autoimmune mechanisms rather than infections, and its pathogenesis is not closely linked to hepatitis B.
